repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Competitiveness Enhancement
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Competitiveness Enhancement
            Technical Assistance Project for El Salvador had the
            following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that a broad Project design compatible and
            supportive of an overall National Competitiveness Strategy
            contributed to the Project's success. Close
            coordination with the private sector can enhance project
            success. Private-Public sector collaboration can be
            strengthened by creating a high-level Coordination Group
            supported by a Technical Secretariat to help implement
            reforms. Broad competitiveness operations are complex and
            risky. Careful attention to supervision and private sector
            involvement are useful in reducing risk. Modernizing the
            legal framework should be the first step in institutional
            development. The order and timeliness of reforms can alter
            the efficacy of outcomes. Public sector agencies are not
            ideal managers of Matching-Grant Programs.

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Competitiveness Enhancement
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Competitiveness Enhancement
            Technical Assistance Project will support the
            Government's program to accelerate outward-oriented
            private sector development and raise productivity. To start
            moving toward these desirable long-term objectives, the
            project will facilitate change by improving the enabling
            environment in three areas: 1) the business environment,
            lowering the cost of doing business in El Salvador; 2) the
            environment for technological capabilities of private sector
            enterprises and labor, in order to raise productivity and
            international competiveness; and 3) the environment for
            building consensus on economic competitiveness issues, by
            facilitating the flow of public information and public
            sector-private sector dialogue.
